thread.title: Palm Island riots racism court ruling appeal dropped, Queensland Government says - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: Palm Island riots racism court ruling appeal dropped, Queensland Government says - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

title: Palm Island riots racism court ruling appeal dropped, Queensland Government says - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Palm Island riots racism court ruling appeal dropped, Queensland Government says Posted February 28, 2017 12:01:41 
Attorney-General Yvette D'Ath said the state took advice before lodging the appeal , but had now decided not to go ahead. 
"Having received a further considered legal advice about the state's prospects of success on appeal, the state is withdrawing the appeal to the full Federal Court," Ms D'Ath said. 
"I note that there are continuing matters still being resolved by the trial judge and those matters will continue before the court." 
The appeal had provoked anger on Palm Island where locals felt the State Government and police should accept the court's finding. 
But the QPS supported the decision appeal. 
More than 16,000 people signed a petition demanding the Government and Queensland Police Service (QPS) drop their appeal against that decision. 
QPS treatment of Aboriginal witnesses was criticised, as well as their failure to move Sergeant Chris Hurley, who was Cameron Doomadgee's arresting officer, from the island. 
The Federal Court ruling last year came in response to Indigenous activist Lex Wotton's legal action on behalf of Palm Islanders after he was jailed for inciting violence following the death of Mr Doomadgee. 
Mr Doomadgee, 36, died of massive internal injuries after he was arrested for being drunk and locked in a police cell on November 19, 2004. 
Arresting officer Senior Sergeant Chris Hurley was charged over Mr Doomadgee's death, but a jury acquitted him of manslaughter in 2007.
